study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits and safety of Calendula officinalis hydroglycolic extract in treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: The study found that Calendula officinalis extract significantly improved DFU healing, with 78% achieving complete wound closure after 30 weeks, reduced microbial colonization, and decreased necrotic tissue and exudate. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-90 with stable neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (Wagner type 1-2), adequate glycemic control, and no allergies to Calendula officinalis.
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of hydroglycolic extract spray solution.
study_duration: Up to 30 weeks or until healing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different concentrations of sodium azide (SA) and diethyl sulfate (DES) on vegetative growth and flowering characteristics in Calendula Officinalis across two generations (M1 and M2).
results_summary: Lower concentrations of SA (1000 ppm) and DES (4000 ppm) improved seed germination, plant height, leaf area, plant fresh weight, flowering date, inflorescence diameter, and gas-exchange measurements. Higher mutagen concentrations delayed flowering, while lower concentrations promoted earlier flowering and better physiological performance.
population_specificity: Calendula Officinalis plants (M1 and M2 generations)
effective_dosage: 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, and 5000 ppm of SA and DES

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the healing effects of Calendula officinalis hydroalcoholic extract in rats with experimentally induced ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The study found that both oral (3000 mg/kg) and enema (20% gel) forms of Calendula officinalis significantly improved body weight, reduced inflammation, and modulated oxidative stress markers in rats with ulcerative colitis. The effects were comparable to standard treatments like mesalamine.
population_specificity: Rats weighing 200 ± 20 g with experimentally induced ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: 1500 mg/kg and 3000 mg/kg orally; 10% and 20% gel enema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ethanolic floral extract of Calendula officinalis could protect against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity by restoring antioxidant systems in renal tissue.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula officinalis extract restored antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced oxidative stress markers, and mitigated cisplatin-induced kidney damage, as supported by biochemical and histopathological findings.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of gelatin-collagen microparticle-loaded scaffolds for improved association with and prolonged release of Calendula officinalis extract in wound treatment.
results_summary: The study found that incorporating gelatin-collagen microparticles enhanced scaffold resistance to enzymatic degradation, improved association with Calendula officinalis extract, reduced cytotoxicity, and prolonged extract release compared to control scaffolds.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: To examine the effect of hydroalcoholic extract of Calendula officinalis on passive avoidance learning and memory in streptozotocin-induced diabetic male rats.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula officinalis extract significantly improved learning and memory impairments in diabetic rats, partially reduced hyperglycemia, and mitigated body weight loss. The extract showed positive effects in retention tests after 24 and 48 hours.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Calendula officinalis compared to Essential Fatty Acids in preventing and treating radiodermatitis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: Calendula officinalis demonstrated superior efficacy compared to Essential Fatty Acids, with statistically significant evidence showing a lower proportion of grade 2 radiodermatitis and a reduced risk of developing grade 1 radiodermatitis. The Kaplan-Meier survival curve further supported Calendula's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 51 patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Calendula officinalis tincture (CDOT) in promoting wound healing by examining its effects on fibroblast proliferation and migration, as well as identifying the active compounds responsible.
results_summary: CDOT significantly stimulated fibroblast proliferation and migration via a PI3K-dependent pathway, evidenced by increased phosphorylation of FAK and Akt. HPLC-ESI MS identified flavonol glycosides as the major compounds likely responsible for the wound-healing activity.
population_specificity: Fibroblasts (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effect of Calendula officinalis flower extract (COE) against monosodium glutamate (MSG)-induced neurotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: COE significantly attenuated behavioral alterations, oxidative stress, and hippocampal damage in MSG-treated rats, suggesting neuroprotective effects likely due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Calendula officinalis (C.O) with Shampoo-clay (S.C) in treating infantile diaper rash.
results_summary: Calendula officinalis showed a 40% healing rate in the first 6 hours and a 36.7% complete recovery rate in 3 days, significantly lower than Shampoo-clay's effectiveness. The study concluded that C.O was less effective and slower-acting compared to S.C.
population_specificity: 60 outpatient infants with diaper rash, referred to health care centers or pediatric clinics in Khomein city.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effect of Calendula officinalis flower extract (COE) on 3-NP-induced neurotoxicity in rats, focusing on behavioral changes, oxidative stress, and striatal damage.
results_summary: COE significantly attenuated behavioral alterations, oxidative damage, and striatal neuronal loss in 3-NP-treated rats, suggesting its neuroprotective action may be due to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and estrogenic properties.
population_specificity: Adult female Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Calendula officinalis extract mouthwash on reducing radiation-induced oropharyngeal mucositis in head-and-neck cancer patients.
results_summary: Calendula mouthwash significantly reduced the intensity of oropharyngeal mucositis compared to placebo at weeks 2, 3, and 6, with higher antioxidant, polyphenol, and flavonoid contents potentially contributing to its efficacy.
population_specificity: 40 patients with head-and-neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy or concurrent chemoradiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 2% calendula extract mouthwash (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant properties and hepatorenoprotective potential of Calendula officinalis extract against aflatoxin-induced liver damage in rats.
results_summary: Calendula extract, particularly the ethanol extract, showed high phenolic content and antioxidant activity. It improved biochemical parameters, reduced oxidative stress, and enhanced liver histology in rats exposed to aflatoxins, with effects being dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg (low dose) and 1000 mg/kg (high dose) body weight

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy and safety of Calendula officinalis ointment versus aloe vera cream in treating diaper dermatitis in infants.
results_summary: Calendula ointment significantly reduced the number of rash sites compared to aloe vera cream, with both treatments improving dermatitis severity. No adverse effects were reported for either treatment.
population_specificity: Infants under 3 years old with diaper dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of topical Calendula officinalis extract in healing oral mucositis induced by 5-fluorouracil in hamsters.
results_summary: Both 5% and 10% Calendula officinalis gel reduced microscopic and macroscopic mucositis scores and promoted weight gain compared to control groups, with statistically significant results (P < .05).
population_specificity: 60 male hamsters with induced oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: 5% and 10% Calendula officinalis gel applied topically.
study_duration: Treatment administered from days 12 to 17 (6 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Calendula officinalis extract in treating experimentally induced ulcerative colitis in a dog model.
results_summary: Calendula officinalis successfully resolved the damages caused by ulcerative colitis, including crypt damage, loss of epithelium, inflammatory cell infiltration, and goblet cell depletion. The treatment also alleviated symptoms like loose stools, diarrhea, and gross bleeding.
population_specificity: 10 female German dogs (1-2 years old, 20-25 kg) with experimentally induced ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a topical gel containing Calendula Officinalis and clobetasol propionate in treating desquamative gingivitis in patients with lichen planus.
results_summary: The study found that the treatment led to remission of symptoms during use and delayed, less severe symptomatic outbreaks after discontinuation over a two-year follow-up. The combination therapy appeared effective in reducing the length and severity of desquamative gingivitis outbreaks.
population_specificity: Two patients with lichen planus presenting as desquamative gingivitis who had previously failed other treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a topical preparation of Calendula officinalis could effectively treat recurrent exfoliative cheilitis.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula officinalis ointment 10% improved the chronic dry scaling lesion on the patient's lips after corticoid therapy was suspended, suggesting its potential as a therapy for exfoliative cheilitis.
population_specificity: An 18-year-old man with recurrent exfoliative cheilitis.
effective_dosage: Calendula officinalis ointment 10% for ad libitum use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of Calendula officinalis extract in preventing UV irradiation-induced oxidative stress in skin, assessing its antioxidant properties and cytotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula officinalis extract exhibited dose-dependent antioxidant effects, was non-cytotoxic at concentrations ≤15 mg/mL, and maintained glutathione levels in UVB-exposed mice while modulating MMP-2 and -9 activity.
population_specificity: Hairless mice (in vivo), L929 and HepG2 cells (in vitro)
effective_dosage: 150 and 300 mg/kg (oral, in vivo); ≤15 mg/mL (non-toxic in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing effects of oral and topical Calendula officinalis extract in rats with excision wounds.
results_summary: Calendula officinalis extract significantly improved wound closure (90.0% vs. 51.1% in controls), reduced re-epithelization time (14-13 days vs. 17.7 days), and increased hydroxy proline and hexosamine content in treated wounds.
population_specificity: Rats with excision wounds

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Calendula Officinalis flower extract against CCl4-induced acute hepatotoxicity and cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity.
results_summary: The extract significantly reduced liver injury markers (SGPT, SGOT, ALP) and kidney function markers (urea, creatinine) in pretreated groups. It also enhanced antioxidant enzymes (superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione) and ameliorated cisplatin-induced myelosuppression.
population_specificity: Animals (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a hydroalcohol extract of Calendula officinalis on reproductive function in male and pregnant female Wistar rats.
results_summary: The extract did not affect male reproductive parameters or show toxicity during early and middle pregnancy but caused maternal weight reduction when administered during the fetal period.
population_specificity: Adult male and pregnant female Wistar rats.
effective_dosage: 0.25, 0.5, and 1.0 g/kg orally for 60 days (males) or during specific pregnancy periods (females).
study_duration: 60 days for males; varied pregnancy periods for females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of Calendula Officinalis extract in animal models of acute and chronic inflammation.
results_summary: Calendula extract significantly reduced paw edema in acute inflammation models (carrageenan and dextran-induced) and inhibited proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1beta, IL-6, TNF-alpha, IFN-gamma) and Cox-2 levels in mice. The extract also suppressed TNF-alpha production in macrophage cultures treated with LPS.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice) with induced inflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of topically administered Calendula officinalis in wound healing through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The review found weak evidence supporting the use of Calendula for acute and chronic wounds, with only one trial of good quality identified. Further research is needed to determine its role in mainstream wound care.
population_specificity: Patients with acute or chronic wounds (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of Calendula officinalis propylene glycol extracts against oxidative DNA damage and lipid peroxidation induced by high PUFA intake in young growing pigs.
results_summary: Calendula officinalis extract from petals (C. officinalis 1) effectively protected DNA from oxidative damage and showed a trend in reducing plasma MDA and urinary iPF2α-VI excretion, with effects comparable to vitamin E. The extract from flower tops (C. officinalis 2) exhibited less antioxidant potential.
population_specificity: Young growing pigs
effective_dosage: 3 ml/day of C. officinalis propylene glycol extracts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the fungicide Zato 50 WG in protecting Calendula officinalis against Erysiphe cichoracearum (powdery mildew).
results_summary: The study found that Zato 50 WG significantly reduced the mean infestation degree of Calendula officinalis leaves by Erysiphe cichoracearum compared to the control, with the 0.2% dose showing the best suitability for protection.
population_specificity: Calendula officinalis (Pot marigold) plants infected with Erysiphe cichoracearum.
effective_dosage: 0.1%, 0.15%, and 0.2% concentrations of Zato 50 WG, applied four times per year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic efficacy of Calendula officinalis extract on the epithelialization of lower leg venous ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with marigold extract ointment significantly accelerated wound healing, reducing ulcer surface area by 41.71% compared to 14.52% in the control group, with complete epithelialization achieved in seven patients. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: 34 patients with venous leg ulcers (21 in the experimental group, 13 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Ointment applied twice daily (specific extract concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute and subacute toxicity of Calendula officinalis hydroalcohol extract (HAE) in rats and mice, focusing on hematological, biochemical, and morphological effects.
results_summary: HAE showed no acute toxicity at doses up to 5.0 g/kg and no hematological alterations at lower doses. However, increased BUN and ALT levels suggested renal and liver overload, with inflammatory sites observed in the lung and liver.
population_specificity: Rats and mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Calendula Officinalis (marigold) and rosemary extracts against experimentally induced irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that cream preparations containing marigold and rosemary extracts showed a statistically significant protective effect against ICD when applied during the induction phase, as measured by chromametry and tewametry. However, post-irritation treatment showed no effect.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers with experimentally induced irritant contact dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested in base cream DAC).
study_duration: 4-day repetitive irritation test for induction phase; 5-day sequential treatment for post-irritation phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between the beneficial properties of Calendula Officinalis and its antioxidant action, focusing on its free radical scavenging effects.
results_summary: The butanolic fraction of Calendula Officinalis demonstrated significant free radical scavenging and antioxidant activity, with IC50 values of 1.0 mg/ml for superoxide radicals and 0.5 mg/ml for hydroxyl radicals, and 100% inhibition of lipid peroxidation at 0.5 mg/ml. The results suggest that its therapeutic efficacy may be partly due to these properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using liver microsomes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Calendula Officinalis ointment with trolamine in preventing acute dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing postoperative radiotherapy.
results_summary: Calendula significantly reduced the occurrence of grade 2 or higher acute dermatitis (41% vs. 63%) compared to trolamine, decreased radiotherapy interruptions, and reduced radiation-induced pain, though it was harder to apply. Patient satisfaction was higher with Calendula.
population_specificity: 254 breast cancer patients post-operation receiving adjuvant radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Applied to irradiated fields after each radiotherapy session (specific quantity not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of radiotherapy (exact length not specified, study conducted between July 1999 and June 2001).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extracts of Calendula officinalis flowers could inhibit HIV-1 replication and protect human lymphocytic cells from HIV-1-induced fusion and death.
results_summary: The organic extract of Calendula officinalis demonstrated potent anti-HIV activity, protecting uninfected cells from fusion and death caused by HIV-1-infected cells, and significantly reduced HIV-1 reverse transcriptase activity in a dose- and time-dependent manner. An 85% inhibition of reverse transcriptase was achieved in a cell-free system.
population_specificity: Human lymphocytic Molt-4 cells and persistently infected U-937/HIV-1 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Calendula Officinalis, both alone and in combination with antacid, in treating duodenal ulcer and gastroduodenitis.
results_summary: The herb combination alleviated spontaneous pains in 90% of patients and dyspeptic complaints in over 85%, with faster relief observed when combined with antacid. Gastric acidity showed a statistically insignificant decrease, and ulcer healing rates were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: 170 patients with duodenal ulcer (99) or gastroduodenitis (71).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the knowledge and usage patterns of Calendula Officinalis among head-neck cancer patients and medical students for treating oral discomfort.
results_summary: Calendula Officinalis was among the top five most commonly known and used plants in both groups, indicating its popularity for oral discomfort. However, the study did not specifically evaluate its efficacy or safety in detail.
population_specificity: Head-neck cancer patients (under surveillance or post-treatment) and medical students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Calendula Officinalis in treating oral mucositis induced by cancer treatment.
results_summary: Calendula Officinalis was found to improve oral mucositis lesions in cancer patients, contributing to reduced severity and better symptom management. The study grouped it among other plant extracts showing positive effects.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with oral mucositis lesions induced by oncotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the components and enzymatic processes involved in the esterification of steryl glucosides in Calendula officinalis.
results_summary: The study found that fatty acids C12-C22 are components of acylated steryl glucosides in Calendula officinalis, and that membranous structures, likely fragments of the Golgi complex, catalyze their esterification. The soluble acyltransferase preparation utilized phospholipids from the same plant, with phosphatidylinositol being the most effective acyl donor.
population_specificity: 14-day-old seedlings of Calendula officinalis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a spray skin protectant versus a moisturiser based on Calendula officinalis and Aloe barbadensis in preventing radiodermatitis with moist desquamation in anal canal and rectal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that the spray skin protectant was more effective than the Calendula-based moisturiser in preventing radiodermatitis with moist desquamation and delaying its onset. However, there was no difference between the groups in the severity of radiodermatitis or discontinuation rates of radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with anal canal and rectal cancer undergoing radiotherapy in a hospital in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (n=63).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a herb combination, including Calendula Officinalis, in treating chronic non-specific colitis.
results_summary: The treatment resulted in the disappearance of spontaneous and palpable pains in 95.83% of patients by day 15, normalized defecation in patients with obstipation and diarrhea syndromes, and eliminated pathological admixtures in feces.
population_specificity: 24 patients with chronic non-specific colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical observations on the prevention of radiodermatitis by Calendula Officinalis and other plant products in patients undergoing curative radiotherapy.
results_summary: The review highlighted Calendula Officinalis as a potential skincare agent against radiation-induced dermatitis, attributing its protective effects to free radical scavenging, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and wound-healing properties. However, specific clinical outcomes for Calendula Officinalis were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Human cancer patients undergoing curative radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Calendula Officinalis in preventing and treating radiodermatitis in radiotherapy patients.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula Officinalis was effective for preventing and treating radiodermatitis, supported by a high level of evidence and recommendation grade. However, the overall quality of evidence for nursing interventions, including Calendula, was noted as weak.
population_specificity: Radiotherapy patients experiencing or at risk of radiodermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the nephroprotective effects of natural compounds, including Calendula Officinalis, against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in preclinical models.
results_summary: The study conducted a meta-analysis of 152 preclinical articles but did not specify findings for Calendula Officinalis. It highlighted a disconnection between preclinical and clinical research regarding natural mixtures' efficacy.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (animal studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of topical Calendula officinalis versus standard care (Sorbolene) in reducing radiation-induced dermatitis in women undergoing breast cancer radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found no detectable difference in the prevalence of grade 2+ radiation-induced dermatitis between Calendula (53%) and Sorbolene (62%) groups, though the study was underpowered due to limited recruitment.
population_specificity: Women undergoing breast cancer radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the traditional use of Calendula Officinalis in wound healing and assess its pharmacological validation through existing scientific studies.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula Officinalis is traditionally used for wound healing, with its efficacy supported by 6 laboratory studies and 1 clinical trial. However, quantitative benefits and specific active compounds remain understudied.
population_specificity: Not specified (general Balkan traditional medicine context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the ethnopharmaceutical knowledge regarding traditional use of Calendula Officinalis in the Samogitia region and compare it with prior research.
results_summary: Calendula Officinalis was one of the most commonly used medicinal plants, with 96.4% of respondents reporting its use for therapeutic purposes. The study highlighted its popularity but did not detail specific therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: 28 respondents aged 50-92 years in the Samogitia region of Lithuania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Calendula Officinalis in cream formulations for protecting skin against UVR-induced damage and aging.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Calendula Officinalis, among other botanicals, may offer photo-protective effects by quenching reactive oxygen species (ROS), but evidence-based studies for its anti-aging effects are still needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dermatologic use implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-atherosclerotic effects of a herbal preparation ("Inflaminat") containing Calendula Officinalis, among other ingredients, in preventing and treating atherosclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that "Inflaminat," which includes Calendula Officinalis, reduced carotid intima-media thickness (IMT) progression, indicating anti-atherosclerotic effects, based on a 2-year double-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial.
population_specificity: Patients with subclinical atherosclerosis (specific details not provided).
effective_dosage: Not specified for Calendula Officinalis individually.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to prepare topical formulations containing natural anti-inflammatory agents, including Calendula Officinalis, for treating rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Calendula Officinalis's effects, only mentioning its inclusion in formulations.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of Calendula Officinalis-derived cosmetic ingredients for human use.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula Officinalis ingredients were not significantly toxic, genotoxic, irritating, sensitizing, or photosensitizing, though they may be mild ocular irritants. The CIR Expert Panel concluded these ingredients are safe for cosmetic use under specified conditions.
population_specificity: Animal and clinical test subjects (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential and clinical evidence of Calendula Officinalis among other plant extracts, focusing on anti-inflammatory activity and overall efficacy.
results_summary: Calendula Officinalis was identified as one of nine plants with considerable evidence of therapeutic effect, supported by clinical trials, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The review highlighted its inclusion among plants with strong pharmacological support.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of dietary interventions or nutritional supplements, including Camel's Milk, for children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Camel's Milk specifically, focusing instead on other supplements and dietary approaches like Ω-3 and gluten/casein-free diets, which showed limited evidence of efficacy.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vaginal gel containing Calendula Officinalis extract, among other ingredients, was more effective than no topical treatment in alleviating symptoms of postmenopausal vaginal dystrophy.
results_summary: The study found that the vaginal gel significantly reduced symptoms like itching, burning, vulvovaginal erythema, vaginal dryness, and dyspareunia compared to no topical treatment. The combination of oral and topical isoflavones was more effective than oral treatment alone.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with vaginal dystrophy (mean age 53.7 years, postmenopausal for 4.1 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified for Calendula Officinalis extract alone (gel contained multiple active ingredients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective efficacy of CBD-loaded niosomes administered via intravitreal injection in treating retinal ischemia in rats.
results_summary: CBD-loaded niosomes preserved retinal function and structure, showing higher b-wave amplitudes and reduced ischemic damage compared to controls. The formulation demonstrated good tolerance and stability, suggesting significant neuroprotective potential.
population_specificity: Rats with induced retinal ischemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if CBD is effective in reducing aggression in Siamese fighting fish (Betta splendens) induced by territorial interactions.
results_summary: CBD reduced the odds of aggressive behavior in treated fish, with only 17% of CBD-treated fish displaying aggression compared to 75% of control fish. The low CBD dose was particularly effective at preventing aggression, though fish appeared more lethargic, and CBD did not reduce the duration of aggressive behaviors when they occurred.
population_specificity: Siamese fighting fish (Betta splendens)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cannabidiol (CBD) in managing chemotherapy-induced pain and its potential role in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that CBD demonstrated anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties, effectively managing chemotherapy-induced pain and showing potential in cancer treatment. Various formulations and nano-formulations of CBD were also summarized.
population_specificity: Cancer patients experiencing chemotherapy-induced pain.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of sublingual CBD on clinical outcomes and inflammatory cytokine levels in patients with SARS-CoV-2.
results_summary: Patients receiving sublingual CBD had better clinical outcomes compared to the placebo group, but serum cytokine levels showed mixed trends. Further study is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with SARS-CoV-2 (7 in treatment arm, 3 in placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of switching or starting treatment with a new commercial pharmaceutical-grade CBD product in patients with drug-resistant epilepsy.
results_summary: Among patients who completed follow-up, 44% reduced seizure frequency, 33% showed no change, and 22% increased seizure frequency. According to the PGIC scale, 50% remained unchanged, 28% reported barely noticeable changes, and 22% reported improvement, with adverse events being mild and transient.
population_specificity: Patients with drug-resistant epilepsy (7 pediatric and 12 adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological effects of CBD in a mouse model of stress-induced liver injury, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and liver-protective properties.
results_summary: CBD significantly reduced liver injury markers (AST, ALT), inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α), and liver fibrosis (α-SMA). It also improved mitochondrial morphology and oxidative stress markers (SOD, GSH-Px) via CB2R/α-SMA and SLC7A11/ACSL4 pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with stress-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a standardized Cannabis sativa extract (CSE), primarily composed of THC/CBD in equimolar concentrations, on neuroinflammation, secondary damage, and locomotor recovery after spinal cord injury (SCI) in rats.
results_summary: CSE therapy reduced pro-inflammatory microglial cells and reactive astrocytes, downregulated inflammatory mediators, and upregulated anti-inflammatory markers. It also prevented cyst expansion, increased spared tissue volume, and improved locomotor outcomes in SCI rats.
population_specificity: Rats with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CBD-coated fabric used as a pillow cover could improve sleep quality in duty shift nurses.
results_summary: The study found that using a CBD-coated pillow cover significantly improved subjective sleep quality, with 7.3% of participants achieving PSQI scores <5, and modest increases in light and deep sleep durations. A significant reduction in anxiety levels was also reported.
population_specificity: Duty shift nurses (55 participants: 10 men, 45 women) with poor sleep quality (PSQI ≥ 5 at baseline).
study_duration: 2-week intervention period, followed by a 1-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of CBD in managing temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) by assessing its analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and muscle-relaxing effects.
results_summary: Studies suggest CBD modulates CB1 and CB2 receptors, reduces cytokine release, and influences neurotransmitter pathways, potentially alleviating TMD-related pain and muscle tension with minimal adverse effects, though high-quality clinical trials are limited.
population_specificity: Individuals with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vaporized CBD13/THC9 in improving disability progression, muscle spasticity, and urine bladder dysfunction in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in muscle spasticity (MAS scores), urine bladder function (PVR volume), and a slight reduction in disability progression (EDSS scores) over six months. Higher CBD13/THC9 doses correlated with slightly lower EDSS scores, and adverse effects were negatively associated with cannabinoid use frequency.
population_specificity: 69 MS patients with debilitating symptoms.
effective_dosage: Vaporized CBD13/THC9 (13.0% CBD + 9.0% THC), dosage frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of CBD and risperidone in a rat model of schizophrenia, focusing on behavioral, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammatory outcomes.
results_summary: CBD restored ketamine-induced behavioral deficits without causing anhedonia, unlike risperidone, and reduced oxidative stress and neuroinflammation in key brain regions, suggesting potential antipsychotic effects mediated by antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: Rat model of schizophrenia induced by sub-chronic ketamine.
study_duration: 8 days of CBD or risperidone treatment following 10 days of ketamine or saline pre-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of topical cannabinoid therapy (30% CBD and 5% CBG) in improving skin parameters and managing atopic dermatitis (AD) symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the topical ointment improved skin hydration, sebum levels, and transepidermal water loss (TEWL) while reducing erythema, suggesting potential as an alternative therapy for AD flare-ups and remission.
population_specificity: Nine patients (five men and four women) aged 20-67 years diagnosed with atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 30% CBD and 5% CBG in a compounded ointment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of highly purified CBD in patients with monogenic epilepsies and examine potential relationships between genetic subgroups and treatment response.
results_summary: The study found a mean seizure reduction of 38.6%, with 47.5% of patients achieving ≥50% seizure reduction and 7.4% achieving seizure freedom. Clinical improvement was noted in 65.8% of patients, with effectiveness varying by pre-treatment seizure history and intellectual disability but not by epilepsy syndrome or off-label use.
population_specificity: Patients with monogenic epileptic disorders (pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants), median age 12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cannabinoids, including CBD, on immune-related adverse events (ir-AE) and clinical outcomes in cancer patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) immunotherapy.
results_summary: Cannabinoids, including CBD, were found to attenuate ir-AE and improve tolerability of ICI immunotherapy, but no significant benefits on survival or cancer progression were observed. Some studies noted adverse effects on the clinical benefits of ICI when cannabinoids were administered concurrently.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) immunotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory efficacy of Calendula Officinalis L. through a systematic review of human intervention studies.
results_summary: The study found no papers regarding the anti-inflammatory effects of Calendula Officinalis L. when used orally, indicating a lack of evidence for its efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of available studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ethnopharmacological uses of Calendula Officinalis for ophthalmological problems and assess its potential effectiveness based on traditional knowledge and preliminary pharmacological studies.
results_summary: The study found that Calendula Officinalis was frequently cited for treating various eye-related issues, such as conjunctivitis and irritated eyelids, and was highlighted as one of the plants deserving further pharmacological research due to its ethnobotanical and preliminary efficacy. However, its pharmacological validation by official international organisms was not confirmed.
population_specificity: 686 informants across 267 locations in Navarra, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of CBD oil on pancreatic islets in Wistar rats under a hypercaloric diet (HCD) to understand its potential therapeutic role in metabolic alterations like diabetes.
results_summary: CBD reduced body weight and food intake, increased fluid consumption, and ameliorated HCD effects by altering insulin, glucagon, and GPR55 receptor expressions. In HCD-fed rats, CBD decreased glycaemia, insulinaemia, and islet area while increasing insulin and glucagon expression.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats under normal or hypercaloric diets.
effective_dosage: 21 mg/kg orally, 0.5 ml, 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of CBD full-spectrum oil extracts as part of symptomatic treatment for Phelan-McDermid syndrome (PMS).
results_summary: CBD was used among various treatment modalities to ease symptoms in PMS patients, with variable results reported; no specific efficacy data or statistical outcomes were detailed.
population_specificity: 17 individuals with Phelan-McDermid syndrome (PMS), aged 2.5-36 years, all of Jewish descent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of CBD on alcohol cue-induced neural activation, craving, mood, and cognitive functioning in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD).
results_summary: CBD did not significantly affect alcohol cue-elicited neural activation, craving, mood, or cognitive functioning compared to placebo, but exploratory analysis showed CBD modulated precuneus activity during cue exposure.
population_specificity: 22 non-treatment seeking individuals diagnosed with AUD (average age 29).
study_duration: Single administration (cross-over design with two fMRI sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CBD could suppress neurotoxic reactive astrocytes, mitigate gliosis, and reduce neuronal loss in a mouse model of epilepsy.
results_summary: CBD suppressed the formation of neurotoxic reactive astrocytes, reduced gliosis and neuronal loss, attenuated seizure symptoms, and enhanced memory capabilities in epileptic mice.
population_specificity: KA-induced epileptic mice and human temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a mouthwash containing CBD and spilanthol on oral microbiota and oral health indicators (BOP and API) in patients with gingivitis, compared to a tea tree oil rinse.
results_summary: The CBD-spilanthol mouthwash significantly reduced bleeding on probing (BOP) and approximal plaque index (API) compared to the tea tree oil rinse, demonstrating efficacy in maintaining oral microbiota homeostasis and providing anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: 40 patients with gingivitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as a mouthwash twice daily for 30 seconds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term behavioral effects of chronic CBD administration during adolescence in mice, particularly in relation to schizophrenia susceptibility and responses to acute THC in adulthood.
results_summary: Adolescent CBD exposure suppressed locomotion, exploration, and social behaviors while reducing anxiety-like behaviors in adult mice. It also exacerbated THC-induced suppression of acoustic startle in genetically susceptible mice but did not alter schizophrenia-relevant behaviors.
population_specificity: Male Neuregulin 1 transmembrane domain heterozygous (Nrg1 TM HET) mice and wildtype-like (WT) controls.
interactions: Exacerbated THC-induced suppression of acoustic startle in Nrg1 mutant mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential effectiveness of CBD as an adjunctive therapy for drug-resistant epilepsy in a pediatric patient with White-Sutton syndrome (WSS).
results_summary: The study found that CBD led to complete seizure remission in a WSS patient with drug-resistant epilepsy, with seizure recurrence upon discontinuation and successful control upon reinstatement. The results suggest CBD may be effective for epilepsy management in WSS.
population_specificity: A single female pediatric patient diagnosed with White-Sutton syndrome and drug-resistant epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the dual mechanism of action of CBD in targeting ion channels and GPR55 to address the epileptogenic cycle in Dravet syndrome.
results_summary: CBD was found to antagonize GPR55 and adjust the synaptic excitatory-inhibitory ratio, effectively breaking the epileptogenic cycle. Preclinical studies supported its efficacy, leading to FDA approval for seizure treatment in Dravet syndrome.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies involving a Dravet syndrome mouse model (Scn1a+/-).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and treatment retention of adjunctive CBD (Epidyolex®) in patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) or Dravet syndrome (DS) when used concomitantly with clobazam (CLB).
results_summary: The study found that CBD reduced seizure frequency significantly, with ≥50% reduction in total seizures observed in 47.5% of patients at 3 months and 45.5% at 12 months. Treatment retention was high (69.8% at 12 months), and adverse events were generally mild (e.g., sedation, diarrhea).
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥2 years with treatment-resistant LGS or DS (126 total: 102 LGS, 24 DS).
effective_dosage: Median target CBD dose was 11.1 mg/kg/day (varied by age group: 17.8 mg/kg/day for <6 years, 15.8 mg/kg/day for 6-17 years, 9.7 mg/kg/day for ≥18 years).
interactions: Concomitant use with clobazam (CLB) was noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cost-effectiveness of adjunctive CBD compared to usual care in patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS).
results_summary: CBD was found to be cost-effective compared to usual care, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of $6573 per QALY. The market access of CBD was associated with a 33% budget increase over 5 years, but it remained sustainable.
population_specificity: Patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS).
study_duration: Lifetime-horizon Markov model (simulated), budget impact analysis over 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetics of CBD in horses following oral administration of two formulations (oil and paste) and assess the influence of feeding time.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between CBD formulations (oil vs. paste) or feeding times (fed vs. fasted). However, the paste formulation achieved peak concentration (Cmax) faster than the oil, suggesting it may be preferable for future equine studies.
population_specificity: Eight healthy horses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor properties of CBD, focusing on its mechanisms of action, including apoptosis, autophagy, and necrosis, across various human tumor cell lines.
results_summary: The study found that CBD activates apoptosis in the majority of cases (68.18%), with some instances of simultaneous apoptosis and autophagy (18.18%), autophagy alone (9.09%), and necrosis (4.54%). The antitumor effects were mediated by transient receptor potential cation channels (TRPVs) in specific cancers.
population_specificity: Human tumor cell lines (endometrial cancer, glioma, bladder cancer, myeloma)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, bioactivity, and potential cosmeceutical applications of CBD, focusing on its effects on skin cells, particularly regarding anti-aging and wound healing.
results_summary: CBD at low concentrations (0.625-2.5 µg/mL) was non-toxic in short-term treatments and enhanced keratinocyte and fibroblast growth in long-term exposure. It demonstrated antioxidant, anti-aging, and wound-healing activities, and influenced skin regenerative gene expression.
population_specificity: Keratinocytes and fibroblasts (in vitro study).
study_duration: Short-term and long-term treatments (specific durations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize nanovesicles incorporating Tween 20 to enhance CBD encapsulation, stability, and performance across the blood-brain barrier (BBB).
results_summary: Nanovesicles with Tween 20 (VS-CBD) showed improved encapsulation efficiency, stability, and controlled release of CBD, with enhanced permeability across the BBB and good biocompatibility. The formulation demonstrated sustained therapeutic effects and reduced dosing frequency.
population_specificity: In vitro models (PAMPA-BBB and hCMEC/D3-BBB cell lines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial and antibiofilm activities of CBD against Gardnerella vaginalis, a bacterium associated with vaginosis.
results_summary: CBD demonstrated strong antibacterial effects against G. vaginalis with a MIC of 2.5 µg/mL, disrupted bacterial membrane function, reduced metabolic activity, and prevented biofilm formation. It also exhibited antioxidant properties and did not interfere with bacterial adherence or phagocytosis.
population_specificity: Clinical isolates of Gardnerella vaginalis and in vitro cell models (HeLa cervical carcinoma cells and RAW264.7 macrophages).
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 2.5 µg/mL CBD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of CBD in targeting HER2-positive ovarian cancer through kinase inhibition, molecular docking, and cell viability assessments.
results_summary: CBD showed strong binding affinity to HER2-TK (KD = 6.16 μM) and effectively inhibited HER2-positive SKOV3 cell growth (IC50 = 13.8 μM), comparable to traditional tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Molecular docking revealed critical interactions with HER2 residues, suggesting potential disruption of HER2-mediated signaling pathways.
population_specificity: HER2-positive ovarian cancer cells (SKOV3)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer activity of CBD from Lebanese Cannabis sativa as a monotherapy and in combination with cisplatin or paclitaxel on human ovarian adenocarcinoma cells.
results_summary: CBD showed dose-dependent tumor growth inhibition with comparable IC50 values for both cell lines. Combination therapy with CBD and cisplatin or paclitaxel showed mixed interactions, ranging from antagonism to mild synergism, depending on the cell line and administration sequence.
population_specificity: Human ovarian adenocarcinoma cell lines (OVCAR-3 and SK-OV-3).
interactions: Antagonistic interaction with cisplatin and paclitaxel in SK-OV-3 cells, mild synergism at high growth inhibition rates, and pure antagonism in OVCAR-3 cells with CBD/cisplatin. Sequential administration showed reduced IC50 values.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of acute CBD treatment (25 mg or 50 mg) compared with placebo on pain, inflammation, and well-being in patients with long bone fractures.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study appears to be ongoing or recently completed without published findings.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-70 years with long bone fractures treated at Hôpital du Sacré-Coeur de Montréal.
effective_dosage: 25 mg or 50 mg of CBD daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetic variability of CBD, including relationships between doses, serum concentrations, metabolites, and biochemical markers of toxicity using therapeutic drug monitoring data.
results_summary: The study found extensive pharmacokinetic variability in CBD, with proposed reference ranges for serum concentrations of CBD and its metabolite 7-OH-CBD. A moderate effect on liver function was observed, and enzyme inhibition by CBD was noted, particularly with clobazam.
population_specificity: 52 patients (48% female, mean age 23, range 3-55 years) with rare and severe epileptic syndromes.
effective_dosage: Mean daily dose of 535 mg (SD 224), approximately 10.03 mg/kg/day.
study_duration: Data collected from January 2022 to June 2023 (18 months).
interactions: Enzyme inhibition by CBD, particularly increasing the concentration ratio of desmethyl-clobazam/clobazam by 140%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CBD improves endurance performance in mice and whether this effect involves the gut microbiome.
results_summary: CBD administration significantly increased treadmill running performance in mice, enhanced oxidative myofiber composition, and promoted mitochondrial biogenesis. CBD also altered the gut microbiome, with Bifidobacterium animalis KBP-1 identified as a key microbe contributing to improved endurance.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specific colorectal cancer (CRC) mutations affect CBD's efficacy in treating CRC and to investigate the role of CB1 and CB2 receptors in CBD's antitumor effects.
results_summary: CBD demonstrated potent antitumor effects in CRC cell lines, inducing apoptosis and inhibiting proliferation, migration, and invasion in a concentration-dependent manner, regardless of underlying mutations. CBD also induced ER stress in CRC cells but not in healthy intestinal organoids, with CB2 receptor activation playing a key role in its anticancer effects.
population_specificity: Four CRC cell lines (HCT116, HT-29, LS174T, LS153) with distinct mutations.
effective_dosage: Range of concentrations (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CBD alone or in combination with THC is effective for managing and treating substance use disorders (SUDs).
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence regarding CBD's efficacy for SUDs, with limited and inconclusive support for abstinence or reduction of substance use. Nabiximols (CBD + THC) showed positive effects on cannabis withdrawal and craving symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance use disorders (cannabis, tobacco, alcohol, opiates, and other psychoactive substances).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CBD could improve insulin sensitivity by modifying sphingolipid metabolism in high-fat diet-induced insulin-resistant rats.
results_summary: CBD prevented ceramide deposition in the liver by inhibiting the ceramide de novo synthesis pathway and increased sphingosine-1-phosphate accumulation, leading to improved insulin signaling in high-fat-fed rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet to induce insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CBD-rich corn oil nanoemulsion on autistic-like behaviors and hippocampal histology in male rats prenatally exposed to valproic acid (VPA).
results_summary: CBD nanoemulsion treatment reversed autistic-like behaviors (reduced anxiety, grooming time, and improved sociability and exploratory activity) and protected against hippocampal neuronal death in VPA-exposed rats. The nanoemulsion formulation showed good stability and reduced vesicle size.
population_specificity: Male rats born to females exposed to valproic acid (VPA) during pregnancy.
effective_dosage: 1 and 2 mg/animal, administered orally twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of purified CBD as an add-on treatment for pediatric patients with severe autism spectrum disorder (ASD) exhibiting treatment-resistant repetitive behaviors and associated comorbidities.
results_summary: CBD treatment improved symptoms in 90% of patients, with notable reductions in irritability, social withdrawal, and hyperactivity, though adverse effects like increased irritability and decreased appetite occurred in 65% of cases. Families reported improved quality of life, and 40% of patients could reduce or discontinue concomitant medications.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with severe ASD and treatment-resistant symptoms.
effective_dosage: Median total dose of 363.5 mg (range: 100-700 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of cannabinoids, including CBD, on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) by examining their antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties.
results_summary: Preclinical studies in SOD1G93A mouse models showed that cannabinoids, including CBD, prolonged neuronal survival, delayed disease onset, and slowed progression. Limited human studies suggested benefits for motor and non-motor symptoms, but further clinical trials are needed for validation.
population_specificity: SOD1G93A murine models and limited human ALS patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically examine transdermal administration of CBD, explore its potential as a systemic delivery route, and compile a literature-based ADME study.
results_summary: The study highlights CBD's therapeutic potential for pain management, epilepsy, anxiety, and other conditions, but notes challenges like poor bioavailability in oral administration. Transdermal delivery emerged as a promising alternative, offering improved bioavailability and targeted effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether CBD could inhibit TRIM14 expression and attenuate NF-κB pathway activation in psoriasis, and evaluate the therapeutic effects of CBD-loaded hydrogel microneedle patches in psoriatic mice.
results_summary: CBD effectively inhibited keratinocyte proliferation, likely by suppressing TRIM14 expression and reducing NF-κB pathway activation. CBD-loaded hydrogel microneedle patches improved psoriasis symptoms (keratoderma thickening, erythema, desquamation) and reduced inflammatory factors in skin tissue and blood, outperforming Tacrolimus cream.
population_specificity: Psoriatic mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the analgesic effects of CBD, both individually and in combination with other nonpsychotropic cannabinoids, on visceral hypersensitivity associated with inflammatory bowel disease.
results_summary: A single injection of 10 mg/kg CBD reduced visceral hypersensitivity and c-Fos activation in the spinal dorsal horn. A combination of subtherapeutic doses of CBD with other cannabinoids also alleviated visceral hypersensitivity without worsening colitis.
population_specificity: Mouse model of dextran sulfate sodium colitis-induced visceral hypersensitivity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of CBD in mitigating neurological damage and inflammation in a rat model of traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: CBD improved neurological deficits, reduced neuronal damage and blood-brain barrier permeability, and suppressed brain injury markers (S-100β and NSE). It also attenuated astrocyte activation, inflammation, and inflammatory prostaglandin system indicators via the PGE2-EP2-cAMP-PKA pathway.
population_specificity: Rat model of TBI (Feeney free-fall method)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mucoadhesive polymers in alleviating chewing difficulties associated with dry mucosal conditions.
results_summary: The study found that mucoadhesive polymers can alleviate chewing difficulties by prolonging residence time on mucosal membranes, thereby easing irritation and restoring physiological conditions.
population_specificity: Individuals with dry mucosal conditions (e.g., dry mouth syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CPP-ACP chewing gum on enamel erosion and abrasion compared to regular sugar-free gum and no gum.
results_summary: CPP-ACP gum significantly reduced enamel lesion depth and surface roughness compared to other groups, but no significant difference was observed when abrasion was involved. Salivary calcium levels did not show significant changes over time.
population_specificity: 10 volunteers in a crossover study

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the latest information on mouth cancer, including risk factors such as chewing habits like betel, for healthcare workers and patients.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes key advances in understanding mouth cancer, highlighting risk factors like tobacco, alcohol, and chewing habits, but does not provide specific findings on chewing's effects.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on healthcare workers, patients, and their carers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the masticatory performance and patient satisfaction between implant-tooth-supported removable partial dental prostheses and implant-supported removable complete dental prostheses.
results_summary: The study found that the edentulous group showed significant improvement in masticatory performance after implant therapy, while the RPDP group did not. Both groups reported increased chewing satisfaction post-therapy.
population_specificity: 30 patients (12 with RPDP, 18 edentulous)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the glycemic effects of Catha edulis (Khat) chewing, balancing its potential hypoglycemic benefits against its association with type 2 diabetes mellitus development.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found conflicting results, with an overall insignificant reduction in blood glucose but a significant elevation in diabetic humans. The variation may stem from unadjusted experimental factors or differences in phytochemical composition.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic and diabetic animals, non-diabetic and diabetic humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify determinants, including khat chewing, associated with increased tuberculosis (TB) occurrence among HIV-infected adults.
results_summary: Chewing khat was identified as an independent determinant for increased TB occurrence (AOR 2.22; 95% CI 1.11 to 4.41), suggesting a negative association with health outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: HIV-infected adults in Northwest Ethiopia (150 cases with active TB, 296 controls without TB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of gum chewing on bowel function recovery and early discharge in women post-caesarean section.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in bowel function recovery or discharge time between the gum chewing, exercise, and control groups, suggesting gum chewing did not outperform other interventions or standard care.
population_specificity: Women who underwent caesarean section at Cengiz Gökçek Gynecology and Obstetrics Hospital.
effective_dosage: Chewed gum for 15 minutes every 2 hours for the first 8 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of self-etching primers (SEP) with traditional hydrophilic primers in orthodontic bonding, focusing on bond failure rates and types.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in bond failure rates between SEP (7.5%) and traditional primers (9%). Cohesive failures were minimal (2%) in both systems, and chewing patterns were noted as a factor in most failures.
population_specificity: 100 patients aged 14+ with healthy teeth and no occlusal interferences, treated in a private orthodontic office in Casablanca.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeinated chewing gum could reduce exercise-induced muscle pain in individuals with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Caffeinated chewing gum did not significantly attenuate exercise-induced muscle pain compared to placebo gum, but more symptomatic individuals with fibromyalgia may benefit more from its use. Clinical pain severity was associated with the average muscle pain rating and caffeine's effects on pain.
population_specificity: Individuals with fibromyalgia (n=23)
study_duration: Single session per condition (caffeine and placebo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the face bow transfer is irrelevant for prosthetic work and orthognathic surgery planning.
results_summary: The study found that the face bow transfer is unnecessary for speech, prosthesis fit and comfort, ridge morphology, facial contours, tooth arrangement, chewing efficiency, and psychological aspects of prosthodontic treatment. Cinefluorographic evidence showed no condylar axis rotation during functional activity, supporting the elimination of this technique.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing prosthetic work or orthognathic surgery planning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of prosthetic restoration for missing posterior teeth on mastication in patients with shortened dental arches.
results_summary: Prosthetic restoration improved objective masticatory performance but had limited subjective benefit in chewing ability, particularly for those with pre-treatment impairment. No significant change in chewing ability was observed in the no-treatment group.
population_specificity: Partially dentate patients with missing posterior teeth (Kennedy Class I or II) recruited from seven university-based dental hospitals in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies on functional outcomes, including chewing, in patients with head and neck cancer to assess health-related quality of life (HRQoL).
results_summary: The study identified chewing as one of the specific functional outcomes in head and neck cancer patients, but no detailed results on its efficacy were provided. The focus was on broader HRQoL domains rather than isolated chewing outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer of the head and neck.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether observing videos of chewing could improve masticatory ability and other related outcomes (e.g., food intake, cognition) in older adults with dementia.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that observing chewing videos would enhance masticatory ability and secondary outcomes like food intake, cognition, and quality of life, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia in residential care settings.
effective_dosage: Videos shown during lunchtime, Monday to Friday.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gum chewing could reduce discomfort in colonoscopy patients consuming a polyethylene glycol bowel-cleansing solution.
results_summary: The gum-chewing group reported significantly lower abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting, and took less time to ingest the solution compared to the control group. The study concluded that gum chewing is an effective, low-cost intervention with no side effects.
population_specificity: Colonoscopy patients in Seoul, Korea.
effective_dosage: One stick of sugarless gum during the pause interval of drinking the solution.
study_duration: The study was conducted from August to October 2012 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of conventional glass ionomer cement (GIC) and resin-modified GIC (RMGIC) as base materials in sandwich restorations on shrinkage-induced crack propensity and fatigue resistance during chewing.
results_summary: Fuji II LC (RMGIC) showed a higher survival rate (40%) compared to Ketac Molar (20%), though the difference was not statistically significant. Super-closed sandwich restorations (SCSR) reduced shrinkage-induced cracks, and most failures were re-restorable.
population_specificity: Extracted maxillary molars (30 samples).
study_duration: Loaded until fracture or up to 185,000 cycles under simulated chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate patients' perception of antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) in managing chronic periodontitis, particularly focusing on symptoms like pain while chewing.
results_summary: Patients receiving SRP with aPDT reported significant reductions in bleeding gums, halitosis, and pain while chewing at 2 weeks and 1 month compared to SRP alone. No significant differences were observed for sensitive gums, procedural pain, or patient acceptance.
population_specificity: 90 patients (51 females, 39 males) with untreated localized chronic periodontitis.
study_duration: 6 months follow-up after a single session of treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test bacterial microleakage at the implant-abutment interface before and after dynamic loading using a chewing simulation to evaluate the bacterial seal of different implant systems.
results_summary: No bacterial contamination was detected under static loading in either group. After dynamic loading, minimal bacterial contamination was observed in one sample from the conical IAC group and two samples from the flat IAC group, indicating conical IACs offer a better bacterial seal.
population_specificity: Implant systems (conical and flat implant-abutment connections)
study_duration: Simulated 1,200,000 chewing cycles (equivalent to 5 years of daily masticatory load)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the functional outcomes of implant-prosthetic treatment on patients who underwent surgical resection of oral cavity tumors, focusing on chewing ability, masticatory performance, and quality of life.
results_summary: Implant-retained prostheses improved masticatory performance and masseter muscle activity on the defect side but not on the non-defect side. While patient satisfaction increased, no general improvement in quality of life was observed.
population_specificity: Patients with mandibulectomy due to oral cavity tumor resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of CPP-ACP in reversing enamel demineralization and provide clinical guidance on remineralization as a treatment option.
results_summary: The study found that CPP-ACP, a protein-based remineralizing technology, can reverse white-spot lesions by promoting subsurface remineralization before surface collapse occurs. It highlighted CPP-ACP's global use in chewing gums and topical creams for this purpose.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of low-level laser therapy could reduce spontaneous and chewing pain after the placement of elastomeric separators.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in spontaneous and chewing pain between the experimental (laser therapy) and control (placebo) groups, indicating that low-level laser therapy effectively reduced postoperative pain.
population_specificity: 88 patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with elastomeric separators.
effective_dosage: 200 mW power, 940-nm gallium-aluminum-arsenic diode laser applied for 20 seconds at 3 points on the buccal mucosa.
study_duration: Single dose, with pain assessed over 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum as a prophylactic intervention for oral mucositis in patients undergoing ambulatory antineoplastic chemotherapy.
results_summary: One study evaluated chewing gum and showed positive results in preventing oral mucositis, but further research is needed to confirm these findings. The abstract does not provide specific details on the efficacy of chewing gum compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing ambulatory antineoplastic chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the mechanical resistance and stress absorption of tooth-colored fiber-reinforced abutments (TCFRAs) versus titanium abutments (TAs) under chewing loads.
results_summary: TCFRAs showed greater elasticity and reduced stress on the bone-implant interface compared to TAs, with fewer fractures/deformations (12.5% vs. 37.5% debonding). TCFRAs exhibited more swinging under load, suggesting better shock absorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (implants and abutments tested in vitro).
study_duration: Not specified (cyclical load testing duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the latest information on mouth cancer, including risk factors such as chewing habits, for healthcare workers and patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the association of chewing habits (e.g., betel) with mouth cancer risk but does not provide specific study results on chewing's effects.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on healthcare workers, patients, and their carers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between chewing-gum use, oral piercing, and symptoms of temporomandibular disorders (TMD) among adolescents.
results_summary: Chewing-gum use was associated with headache, difficulty opening the mouth wide, and tenderness of the temporomandibular joints and muscles. Oral piercing and nail biting were also linked to headache, muscle tenderness, and tooth wear.
population_specificity: 124 third-level high school students (116 clinically examined), including science and media program students from urban and small-town settings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (25% reported daily chewing-gum use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the complex interaction between Mycobacterium tuberculosis lipid metabolism, host immune response, and lipid homeostasis during infection.
results_summary: The study found that M. tuberculosis preferentially associates with foamy cells and utilizes host-derived fatty acids and cholesterol, with host pathways like PPARγ and LXR playing key roles in lipid accumulation during infection.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on pathogen-host interaction, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between TIMP3 polymorphisms (rs9862) and oral cancer susceptibility, particularly in relation to betel quid chewing.
results_summary: The study found that individuals carrying the TIMP3 rs9862 T/T allele had a significantly increased risk of oral cancer, especially among betel quid chewers (32.2-fold higher risk). The polymorphism was also associated with larger tumor development and elevated TIMP3 plasma levels in oral cancer patients.
population_specificity: Taiwanese men (747 oral cancer patients and 1200 healthy controls).
interactions: Betel quid chewing significantly interacted with the TIMP3 rs9862 polymorphism to increase oral cancer risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between high-risk HPV infection and lifestyle habits, including tobacco chewing, in head and neck cancer patients from North-East India.
results_summary: The study found a significant association between tobacco chewing and high-risk HPV infection, particularly HPV-16, in head and neck cancer cases. Tobacco chewing and alcohol consumption were identified as potential risk factors for HPV infection in this population.
population_specificity: Primary head and neck cancer patients from the North-East region of India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of nutritional derangements and the need for nutritional interventions, including adjustments to oral diets based on chewing and swallowing capabilities, in elderly residents of long-term care institutions.
results_summary: The study found that inadequacy of food texture according to chewing and swallowing capabilities was a primary reason for needing to implement oral diet modifications. Nutritional interventions were associated with worse nutritional status, and larger institutions were more likely to require improvements in nutrition care.
population_specificity: Elderly residents (age ≥60 years) in 19 long-term care institutions.
study_duration: Baseline data collected between September 2011 and September 2013 (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interactions between the pharmacological effects of khat chewing and cannabinoids, focusing on their parallel and contrasting behavioral effects.
results_summary: Khat chewing exhibits an amphetamine-like mechanism mediated through the dopaminergic system, with concurrent consumption of khat and cannabinoids increasing psychosis risk, rewarding effects, pain perception threshold, and impairing learning and memory, while cannabis may reduce khat's appetite suppressant effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to Africa and the Middle East due to sociocultural tradition).
interactions: Concurrent consumption of khat and cannabinoids may increase psychosis risk and alter behavioral effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and meloxicam in reducing pain during chewing and other activities after orthodontic separator placement.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain control between acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and meloxicam during chewing or other activities after separator placement. Pain peaked at 24 hours at rest but sometimes at 48 hours during chewing.
population_specificity: Patients aged above 15 needing orthodontic treatment (n=321).
effective_dosage: Group A: 650 mg acetaminophen; Group B: 400 mg ibuprofen; Group C: 7.5 mg meloxicam (single dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of gum chewing for bowel function recovery after left-sided colorectal cancer surgery and determine its physiological mechanism.
results_summary: Gum chewing did not significantly shorten time to first flatus, first bowel movement, or colonic transit time but increased serum levels of des-acyl ghrelin and gastrin. The study found no significant effect on bowel function recovery despite hormonal changes.
population_specificity: Patients with left-sided colorectal cancer (21 in gum group, 22 in control group after exclusions).
effective_dosage: Chewing commercial gum 3 times a day for ≥5 minutes each time.
study_duration: From postoperative day 1 to the first day of food intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biologic activities, metabolism, and therapeutic applications of quercetin, including its release from glycosides through chewing and digestion.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin, released from glycosides during chewing and digestion, exhibits strong antioxidant activity and potential therapeutic benefits for conditions like diabetes, obesity, circulatory dysfunction, inflammation, and mood disorders. It undergoes metabolism in several organs, producing various forms detectable in plasma.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers were examining the use and properties of extended-release (XR) formulations of various medications, including restrictions on chewing or altering the tablets/capsules.
results_summary: The study found that most XR formulations must be swallowed whole to maintain their properties, except for Qudexy XR™, which can be sprinkled on food. Food significantly affects the bioavailability of Gralise(®) and Horizant(®).
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of XR formulations).
interactions: Food (specifically fat content) affects the bioavailability of Gralise(®) and Horizant(®).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction between immediate and conventional loading of fixed complete-arch prostheses for mandibular rehabilitation, focusing on chewing and other functional outcomes.
results_summary: The test group (immediate loading) showed significantly higher satisfaction for chewing initially, but differences disappeared by 12 months. The control group (conventional loading) experienced a significant decrease in chewing satisfaction at 3 months, which later improved.
population_specificity: 36 consecutive patients with failing mandibular dentition (18 in each group).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum reduces postoperative morbidity, particularly gastrointestinal dysfunction, by preserving vagal neural activity after elective orthopedic surgery.
results_summary: Chewing gum did not significantly reduce overall morbidity but did reduce postoperative gastrointestinal dysfunction and shortened the time to become morbidity-free. It was also associated with increased parasympathetic activity contributing to heart rate variability.
